chargeHist.descr: Possess Drug Paraphernalia to Manufacture, Compound, Convert, Produce, or Store Methamphetamine

result.execSummary:
The defendant Cheemoua Thao was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case.

  • Possess w/ Intent-Amphetamine(<=3g) [Modifiers: Repeater], a class F felony, Wisconsin Statutes 961.41(1m)(e)1.

Charge(s) in this case were read in to this or other case(s). A "read in" charge is a charge that is dismissed as part of a plea agreement, however:

  • The defendant agrees to have the court consider the charge(s) when sentencing for another crime, under Wis. Stats. 973.20(1g)(b); and
  • The defendant cannot be prosecuted for these charge(s) in the future.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

supervisions.notes: Concurrent with: any probation or extended supervision now serving.

miscConds.notes: If probation is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if probation is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt.  If the defendant is placed on probation or released to extended supervision, IT IS ORDERED that the defendant pay supervision fees as determined by the Department of Corrections.
Maintain employment, commensurate with his treatment needs.  Not to terminate his employment without his agent's prior approval.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.   Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.

Defendant shall have no contact, directly or indirectly, either personally, by mail, telephone or through any other person, or by any other means with:  Veronica Pfiefer, Laurana Poindexter, Kyle Field, Dale Reichenbach, John Cook,  or the victim, C.V.  

Defendant to be subject to random testing by his agent.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Comply with addict programming recommended by MSDF.  

Court advised defendant of the DNA submission requirement.

Credit for 9 days if revoked.

supervisions.notes:
Credit for 210 days served.
Consecutive to: La Crosse County cases now serving, 13CF286 & 13CF347

superMiscConds.notes: If extended supervision is revoked and a prison term is not ordered, or if extended supervision is discharged or terminated, a civil judgment shall be entered against the defendant in favor of any restitution victims and government entities for outstanding financial obligations.  All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Must pay all costs of supervision and court ordered financial obligations during the term of probation.  Must pay DNA surcharge.

Must seek and maintain full-time employment which is satisfactory to your probation agent, commensurate with treatment needs when agent deems appropriate.  Defendant must not leave or change employment without prior approval of your probation agent.

Must comply with any mental health treatment or programming recommended by your agent.  Defendant must execute all releases of information for assessments, counseling, treatment, to allow probation agent to verify compliance.

Not to possess or consume any controlled substances.  Not to possess any drug paraphernalia.  Not to possess any prescription medications of any kind unless those have been prescribed to the defendant by a physician, and in that case, the defendant shall take such medications only as prescribed.  Defendant shall not alter the form of any prescription prior to, or in conjunction with, ingestion.  Not to associate with any known illegal drug users or dealers.

Not to enter into any bars, taverns, liquor stores, liquor department of grocery stores, the bar areas of restaurants. Defendant may not possess or consume any alcohol, nor be anywhere alcohol is available for consumption on the premises where the defendant is located.

The defendant shall comply with any treatment, evaluations and/or programming as deemed appropriate by a risk and needs assessment and the probation agent.  Defendant must sign any releases agent deems necessary to verify defendant's compliance with probation conditions.

Must comply with any other recommedations of your agent.  

Must submit a DNA sample if not already on file and pay the surcharge.

Defendant must submit to random urinalysis by probation agent or any law enforcement officer.

records.addlTxt: Amendment to JOC and Order - ERP
From DOC
Court's response regarding DOC letter from 12/21/17.  Faxed to DOC this date.  JMM
from Attorney Zachar to Judge Becker.  Judge has a copy, per JA
Sent emails to Attorney Zachar and ADA Inlow instructing that they are to respond to DOC's letter in regards to the jail credit on this case.
From DOC in reference to 210 days sentence credit.  (routed to Judge)

Defendant appears in person in custody with counsel Chris Zachar.  ADA Melissa Inlow appears for the State.  Parties do not note any corrections to the revocation summary.  

State recommends 6-8 years total sentence bifurcated as 3-4 yr initial confinement and 3-4 extended supervision, consecutive to 2013 LaCrosse County cases.  Eligible for both programs in prison.  Defense makes statement to the Court and recommends a sentence of 18 months initial confinement and 18 months extended supervision concurrent to current sentences with with CIP and ERP.  210 days credit.  State has complied with victim rights notification and there are no restitution requests.  Defendant exercises his right to allocution.

Court orders 3 years initial confinement and 2 years on extended supervision consecutive to 2013 La Crosse County cases.  Extended supervision conditions:  Must undergo a risk and needs assessments and comply with any recommendations for treatment, counseling, or programming.  Must sign all releases of information for agent to verify compliance.  Not to possess any drugs unless prescribed.  Not to possess any drug paraphernalia. Not to possess any alcohol or be where sold/served or available for consumption.  Must submit to random drug testing when agent requests.  Must comply with any mental health treatment or programming, or any other recommendations by agent.  Must pay costs, including a DNA surcharge.  Must seek and maintain employment commensurate with treatment needs which is approved by your agent.  Eligible for both programs.  Credit for 210 days served.

Sent to Judge Becker electronically.  Paper copies to the attorneys.  JMM
Sentencing hearing on October 31, 2016 at 01:30 pm.

ADA Melissa Inlow appeared for the State.  Defendant appeared in person, in custody with Attorney Randtke.  Defendant plead guilty to Count 3.  Remaining charges dismissed, but read in for sentencing purposes  Court recited the charge and possible penalties on the count he plead to.  Defendant understood.  Felony warnings given.   Repeater allegation confirmed.  Court reviewed the plea questionnaire, constitutional rights and elements with the defendant.  Defense stipulated that there is a factual basis for the plea.   Court found that the defendant freely, voluntarily, knowingly and intelligently entered his plea and waived his constitutional rights.  Court found that a factual basis exists for the plea.  Found guilty of Possess w/ Intent-Amphetamine (<=3g) contrary to 961.41(1m)(e)1  Wis. Stats, as a repeater.  PSI ordered due 9/30/16.  SEH set for 10/31 at 1:30 p.m.
Plea hearing at 04-18-2016 01:30 pm
Reading of the information waived.  Defense entered NGP.  Court entered NGP on defendant's behalf.  Defense is going to apply for treatment court in La Crosse County.  Plea set for 4/18/16 at 1:30 pm
Information filed in court.

Court found that the defendant knowingly and intelligently waived his right to a preliminary hearing.
